Solutions: Day 4 Exercises

Download this document here.

nlsy_cols <- c("glasses", "eyesight", "sleep_wkdy", "sleep_wknd", 
               "id", "nsibs", "samp", "race_eth", "sex", "region", 
               "income", "res_1980", "res_2002", "age_bir")
nlsy <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/louisahsmith/id543/main/data/nlsy.csv", 
                 na = c("-1", "-2", "-3", "-4", "-5", "-998"),
                 skip = 1, col_names = nlsy_cols) |> 
  mutate(region_cat = factor(region, labels = c("Northeast", "North Central", "South", "West")),
         sex_cat = factor(sex, labels = c("Male", "Female")),
         race_eth_cat = factor(race_eth, labels = c("Hispanic", "Black", "Non-Black, Non-Hispanic")),
         eyesight_cat = factor(eyesight, labels = c("Excellent", "Very good", "Good", "Fair", "Poor"))) 
Rows: 12686 Columns: 14

Exercises 1

Make a tbl_summary(). Include (at least) number of hours of sleep on weekdays and weekends, categorical region, and income and make sure they are nicely labeled. Play around with the extra functions from the example in the slides.

# install.packages("gtsummary")
library(gtsummary)
tbl_summary(nlsy, 
            by = sex_cat,
            include = c(contains("sleep"), income, region_cat, sex_cat),
            label = list(sleep_wkdy ~ "Weekday sleep (hrs)",
                         sleep_wknd ~ "Weekend sleep (hrs)",
                         region_cat ~ "Region",
                         income ~ "Income ($)"),
                            # change all continuous variables to mean, sd
            statistic = list(all_continuous() ~ "{mean} ({sd})",
                             # change income to specific statistic
                             income ~ "10th pctle: ${p10}; 90th pctle: ${p90}",
                             all_categorical() ~ "{n} ({p}%)"),
            # remove missingness
            missing = "no",
            # change to row percentages
            percent = "row") |> 
  # add p-value
  add_p()
Characteristic Male, N = 6,4031 Female, N = 6,2831 p-value2
Weekday sleep (hrs) 6.53 (1.41) 6.60 (1.46) 0.046
Weekend sleep (hrs) 7.14 (1.65) 7.19 (1.69) 0.094
Income ($) 10th pctle: $3,864; 90th pctle: $30,000 10th pctle: $3,068; 90th pctle: $30,000 0.082
Region 0.11
    Northeast 1,296 (51%) 1,254 (49%)
    North Central 1,488 (51%) 1,446 (49%)
    South 2,251 (49%) 2,317 (51%)
    West 1,253 (52%) 1,142 (48%)
1 Mean (SD); 10th pctle: $10%; 90th pctle: $90%; n (%)
2 Wilcoxon rank sum test; Pearson’s Chi-squared test

Exercises 2

Fit a Poisson regression for the number of siblings, using at least 3 predictors of your choice. Calculate the exponentiated coefficients and confidence intervals.

poisson_model <- glm(nsibs ~ income + I(income^2) + region_cat*age_bir,
                     family = poisson(), data = nlsy)

exp(coef(poisson_model))
                    (Intercept)                          income 
                      7.4213002                       0.9999755 
                    I(income^2)         region_catNorth Central 
                      1.0000000                       1.0784901 
                region_catSouth                  region_catWest 
                      1.0104004                       1.0379966 
                        age_bir region_catNorth Central:age_bir 
                      0.9827437                       0.9994832 
        region_catSouth:age_bir          region_catWest:age_bir 
                      1.0030114                       1.0003742

Exercises 3

Create a nice table displaying your Poisson regression.

library(broom)
tidy(poisson_model)
# A tibble: 10 × 5
   term                             estimate std.error statistic   p.value
   <chr>                               <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
 1 (Intercept)                      2.00e+ 0  7.63e- 2   26.3    6.26e-152
 2 income                          -2.45e- 5  1.53e- 6  -16.1    5.08e- 58
 3 I(income^2)                      2.90e-10  2.60e-11   11.2    5.37e- 29
 4 region_catNorth Central          7.56e- 2  9.83e- 2    0.768  4.42e-  1
 5 region_catSouth                  1.03e- 2  8.97e- 2    0.115  9.08e-  1
 6 region_catWest                   3.73e- 2  1.03e- 1    0.361  7.18e-  1
 7 age_bir                         -1.74e- 2  3.03e- 3   -5.74   9.69e-  9
 8 region_catNorth Central:age_bir -5.17e- 4  3.93e- 3   -0.132  8.95e-  1
 9 region_catSouth:age_bir          3.01e- 3  3.61e- 3    0.832  4.05e-  1
10 region_catWest:age_bir           3.74e- 4  4.14e- 3    0.0904 9.28e-  1
tbl_regression(poisson_model,
               exponentiate = TRUE,
               label = list(income ~ "Income",
                            `I(income^2)` ~ "Income^2",
                            region_cat ~ "Region",
                            age_bir ~ "Age at first birth",
                            `region_cat:age_bir` ~ "Region/age interaction")) |> 
  bold_labels()
Characteristic IRR1 95% CI1 p-value
Income 1.00 1.00, 1.00 <0.001
Income^2 1.00 1.00, 1.00 <0.001
Region
    Northeast — —
    North Central 1.08 0.89, 1.31 0.4
    South 1.01 0.85, 1.20 >0.9
    West 1.04 0.85, 1.27 0.7
Age at first birth 0.98 0.98, 0.99 <0.001
Region/age interaction
    North Central * Age at first birth 1.00 0.99, 1.01 0.9
    South * Age at first birth 1.00 1.00, 1.01 0.4
    West * Age at first birth 1.00 0.99, 1.01 >0.9
1 IRR = Incidence Rate Ratio, CI = Confidence Interval

The {broom} package has a couple of other major functions: glance() and augment(). Try out each of them on your regression model. Look at the documentation for each to help you figure out what they do.

# this will output some model statistics
glance(poisson_model)
# A tibble: 1 × 8
  null.deviance df.null  logLik    AIC    BIC deviance df.residual  nobs
          <dbl>   <int>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>       <int> <int>
1         8022.    4695 -10744. 21509. 21573.    7309.        4686  4696
# this will add fitted/predicted values, residuals, and some other
# stats to the original dataframe
augment(poisson_model)
# A tibble: 4,696 × 12
   .rownames nsibs income `I(income^2)` region_cat age_bir .fitted .resid

Exercises 4

Create a scatterplot for nsibs on the y-axis and income on the x-axis. Add a regression line from a Poisson regression to it.

ggplot(data = nlsy, 
       aes(x = income, 
           y = nsibs, 
           color = region_cat)) + # stratify by region
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "glm",
              method.args = list(family = poisson()))
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
Warning: Removed 2505 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`).
Warning: Removed 2505 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
